title: When will Mexico’s Chamber of Deputies approve the Federal Law for the Regulation of Cannabis?
preds:
"Mexican Committees Approve Revised Marijuana Legalization Bill, With Floor Vote Expected Wednesday"
https://www.marijuanamoment.net/mexican-committees-approve-revised-marijuana-legalization-bill-with-floor-vote-expected-wednesday/
https://www.marijuanamoment.net/mexican-lawmakers-circulate-amended-marijuana-legalization-bill-thats-set-for-a-vote-on-monday/ From what I read, the question will likely resolve today. EDIT:
https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/mexico-decriminalizes-recreational-use-of-marijuana/2171916
Resolution suggested.

The Decriminalization issue is likely postponed in a current draft, so selling cannabis will remain prohibited, until further scientific research is made.
https://www.24-horas.mx/2021/03/05/diputados-buscan-echar-la-bolita-a-conadic-para-regular-mariguana/
Let's see how this plays out.

The overarching NGO (?) ALCANN, which supports and promotes across Latin America
the decriminalization of hemp,
the use for medical and recreational use and
wants to seize industrial and export opportunities connected with the initiative in other countries of the world, published the demand for five crucial amendments to the current legislative proposal as late as 09 February 2021, if my reading of Spanish is correct.
https://indicepolitico.com/va-la-alcann-por-cinco-modificaciones-a-la-ley-sobre-la-cannabis/ This means, the "Before 1 March 2021" is already superseded, because as far as I understand the routines of sessions of the "diputados", the February session has already ended, and they will not reconvene before the March session, and the proposal has obviously not yet been accepted. The questions now seem to be,
/how powerful interest groups such as the ALCANN really are, and if they could thus interfere with parliamentary procedures to slow down the acceptance in  order to receive a tailor made law according to their wish list, and
/how controversial the matter fundamentally really is, which could lead to a further delay of the law beyond the term's end and the upcoming elections, which would also require a further extension of the supreme court's deadline. I decided to shift probabilities towards the latter option, since if it was an easily solved topic, it will either be solved in March (or would have been solved in February 2021 altogether), or not at all.

Hearings and discussion seem to be ongoing, after they have been postponed in Dec 2020. However, with a high death toll and ongoing second/third waves of infections (while prospects of achieving immunization through vaccines are limited), there's a study that suggests that a certain variety of marihuana could be beneficial for preventing the outbreak of COVID-19 in users, as it contains chemicals that effectively block SARS-CoV-2 from attaching to the human cell via the ACE2 receptor(in Mexico it is apparently rather consumed as a tea than smoked along with tabacco ). https://www.gq.com.mx/entretenimiento/articulo/marihuana-podria-detener-al-covid-19-afirma-estudio
https://comunicacionnoticias.diputados.gob.mx/comunicacion/index.php/revista/79#page/31 EDIT:
http://sitl.diputados.gob.mx/LXIV_leg/integrantes_de_comisionlxiv.php?comt=31
http://sitl.diputados.gob.mx/LXIV_leg/minutaslxiv.php?comt=31&tipo_turnot=2&edot=P
http://gaceta.diputados.gob.mx/Gaceta/64/2020/oct/20201027-II.html#Iniciativa1
http://sitl.diputados.gob.mx/LXIV_leg/cuadros_comparativos/1PO3/0551-1PO3-20.pdf Past session has been 03/04 Feb 2021, but there's neither clear info about the next session's date nor agenda, nor an indication when the Cámara de Diputados will vote on this item.
Can you get on the bus   -O_O-
Very controversial for a time of crisis. other priorities
